title: CDC Recommends Pregnant Women Receive Covid-19 Vaccine
summary: New CDC research suggests that Pfizer and BioNTech, Moderna vaccines are safe for expectant mothers. Pregnant women should get the Covid-19 vaccine, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Friday, providing the clear guidance that many expecting mothers have sought for months.

title: U.S. Beefing Up Defenses to Aid Afghan Withdrawal
summary: Deployment of B-52 bombers and an aircraft carrier is a signal to the Taliban that the U.S. intends to ensure a peaceful pullout of American forces. title: Donor Disclosure Arrives at the Supreme Court
summary: The Justices hear a major case on privacy and the right of association.. That politics makes strange bedfellows is an old observation, yet Monday's lineup at the Supreme Court remains a sight to behold. On one side is California, which is demanding that nonprofit groups hand over lists of their major donors.

title: The Fed's Real Diversity Problem
summary: The central bank's 'groupthink' isn't about race and gender.. The racial politicization of everything continues, and now it's extending to monetary policy. According to a new Brookings Institution report, a pressing issue at the Federal Reserve is its dominance by white men.

title: Sen. Coons vs. the Covid Vaccine Thieves
summary: A Democrat rebuts the claims of those who want to steal U.S. intellectual property.. Progressives have been pushing on an open door in the Biden Presidency and Democratic Congress, and some bad policy is the result. So it's good to see at least some resistance in the Democratic Party to another destructive idea now advancing politically: Suspending intellectual property for Covid vaccines at the World Trade Organization.

title: A 9-0 Defeat for the FTC
summary: The Supreme Court crushes the agency for abusing the law.. Justice Stephen Breyer in a recent speech challenged the media's partisan characterization of the Supreme Court. On Thursday the Court underscored his point with a 9-0 smackdown of the Federal Trade Commission for rewriting the law to aggrandize its power.

title: Capital-Gains Tax Hike Is on Biden's Radar
summary: Proposal to raise top tax rate revives long-running debate over taxation of labor versus investment income. WASHINGTON-President Biden's capital-gains tax proposals would alter wealthy Americans' investment strategies and reignite the long-running political debates over the link between tax rates and economic growth.

title: Lithia Motors Accelerates Dealer Acquisitions Amid Boom in Car Sales
summary: The Medford, Ore.-based chain is buying regional dealerships to add inventory for its new online sales platform. Lithia Motors Inc. is accelerating the pace of acquisitions of regional auto dealers as it looks to bolster its inventory levels amid a surge in car sales.

summary: Some investors opposed brokerage's practice of routing stock orders to high-speed trading firms. A federal appeals court sided with TD Ameritrade in a legal battle over its practice of routing investors' stock orders to high-speed trading firms in exchange for payments.

summary: Dramatic crash underscores fragility of cryptocurrency's recent gains and vulnerability of individual investors. Bitcoin's rally appears to be running out of steam, at least for now.

Ghislaine Maxwell pleaded not guilty Friday to sex-trafficking counts and charges that she enticed and groomed underage girls for the late disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein, making her first appearance in a Manhattan federal courtroom Friday since her arrest last summer.

title: Maxine Waters's Long History of Reckless Rhetoric
summary: The California congresswoman has never been a peacemaker. She's always been on the side of rioting.. The Ku Klux Klan was in Huntington Beach, Calif., on April 12, holding a "White Lives Matter" rally. It was a 37-minute drive away from the Hawthorne district office of Rep. Maxine Waters. "Auntie Maxine" (as the Democrat calls herself) declined to confront the Klan. But she flew all the way to Minneapolis last weekend to coach protesters awaiting the outcome of the Derek Chauvin trial.

title: How to Have More Police Shootings
summary: Conformity today means you can't be both against police misconduct and against resisting arrest.. By now enough facts have been reported in enough places that it has dawned, if grudgingly, on many Americans that the cavalcade of CEOs who denounced Georgia's election law didn't know in the slightest what they were talking about.

summary: He called for nonpartisan mapmaking. They are rushing to draw theirs without Republican input.. Springfield, Ill.

title: In Mexico, Worries Mount Over Political Interference in the Judiciary
summary: Term of Mexico's Supreme Court chief justice is extended under new law; critics call it a political move by government of President López Obrador. MEXICO CITY-Mexico approved a controversial bill related to the country's courts system that critics see as the latest move by the populist government to interfere in Mexico's judiciary.

title: How Apple and Spotify Are Battling to Be Your Favorite Podcasting Service
summary: Podcasts became even more popular during the lockdown and are on track to rake in more than $1 billion in U.S. ad revenue this year.. Podcasting has exploded in popularity during the coronavirus pandemic, with an estimated 116 million Americans now counting themselves as monthly podcast listeners-an 11% increase over 2020-according to Edison Research and Triton Digital. Apple and Spotify are shaping up to be the dominant players in an all-out war for your ears. Here's how.

title: Stocks Rise, but Decline for the Week
summary: Sentiment has wavered between concerns about Covid-19 and optimism prompted by economic data. Investors piled back into stocks Friday, lifting all three major U.S. indexes, as fresh data underscored that a strong economic recovery is under way.

title: Covid Unemployment Relief Makes Help Impossible to Find
summary: Congress's enhanced benefits make it more remunerative not to work. Employers are struggling.. Christie Phelps came near her Covid breaking point last year as she contended with a naughty 5-year-old boy, "the most hyper child I've ever been around," in her Indianapolis home daycare. On a particularly bad day he urinated on her fence and cursed in front of playmates. Other child-care providers turn children like him away for behavioral problems, but Ms. Phelps realized that "he needs help." These days she also asks herself: "How am I going to keep dealing with all this? This is too much stress. I don't have no one helping me."

title: Bipartisan Group Backs Gas-Tax Increase as Option to Fund Infrastructure
summary: Biden plan and rival GOP proposal have favored other revenue ideas. WASHINGTON-A bipartisan group of House lawmakers endorsed a report that includes raising the gasoline tax as a possible way to pay for infrastructure spending, lending support to a measure that both Republican and Democratic proposals have avoided in the debate about how to cover the cost of an infrastructure package.

title: Boy Scouts Sexual Abuse Claims Threaten Financial Havoc for Insurance Companies
summary: Century could be pushed into insolvency, and Chubb could be dragged into the bankruptcy fight. The cost of compensating victims of the Boy Scouts of America's failure to screen out sexual predators may threaten an insurance company's solvency and could spread to Chubb Ltd. , the country's largest commercial insurer, according to court papers filed by a survivors' group.

title: Citgo Looks to Bolster Corporate Governance With New Compliance Chief
summary: The petroleum refiner has hired Steven Scarpino to lead its compliance program, which previously was overseen by its top legal executive. Citgo Petroleum Corp. has moved to strengthen its corporate governance by creating a dedicated chief compliance officer position with a direct reporting line to its chief executive officer and board of directors.

title: Garland Commits to Police Department Probes With Their Voices at the Table
summary: Police groups express concerns over probes like the one in Minneapolis while recognizing that changes are needed. WASHINGTON-Attorney General Merrick Garland on Friday told leaders of the nation's largest law-enforcement organizations that an investigation into the Minneapolis Police Department will be the first-but not last-broad civil-rights probe of a local agency that the Justice Department intends to launch as it takes a larger role in local policing.

title: Covid-19 Mask Mandates Are Again at Center of Political Battles
summary: Lawmakers in some states are passing new bills to limit governors' powers to create emergency public-health measures. Lawmakers across several states are seeking to limit the powers of governors and other officials who, in the future, may want or need to implement public-health measures such as mask mandates.

How the Academy Behind the Oscars Makes Money
summary: Ratings may drop for the Oscars, but the academy itself is on firm financial ground thanks to its investments and broadcast deals. The Oscars may suffer from declining viewership and a down year for movie releases limited by the pandemic. But the organization that runs Hollywood's most prestigious awards ceremony is on solid financial ground, with a growing collection of assets approaching $1 billion, according to the academy and its affiliates' consolidated financial statements.

title: Some Democrats Push for Permanent Expansion of Unemployment Benefits
summary: Lawmakers want Biden to include payments in antipoverty package set to be rolled out next week. WASHINGTON-Democrats on Capitol Hill are pushing for the White House to propose more generous and long-lasting jobless benefits on a permanent basis as part of the antipoverty package President Biden is expected to roll out next week.

title: 3-D Printing Stocks Are Still Running on Hype
summary: The buzz around the 2013 3-D printing craze turned out to be a stock-market bust. Will this year's speculation be any different?. Back in 2013 it seemed like a 3-D printer was about to become your next home appliance. That hasn't happened, and the hot investing theme collapsed like a house of cards. Now the industry has shown us a new dimension as a crop of "additive manufacturing" companies are printing things ranging from food to tooth straighteners to organ scaffolds for human transplants.

title: Outdoor Lighting Ideas to Make Your Yard Look Like a Luxury Resort
summary: What's the best way to make your outdoor space elegantly enjoyable after dark? With a lighting scheme as layered as your living room's, say the pros. Here's how.. LAST SUMMER, those of us charmed enough to have a backyard to call our own tended our gardens and zhushed our patios with new furniture, maybe even springing for an outdoor rug. When it came to exterior lighting, however, most people aimed no higher than a swag of Edison-bulb string lights and a feebly flickering hurricane candle.

title: Outdoor Lighting Done Right
summary: Take a visual stroll through a North Carolina back yard with a sophisticated outdoor-lighting scheme. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Republicans Need to Get Immigration Straight
summary: There are far more immigrants than woke corporate executives who hire them as cheap labor.. Extolling the virtues of the country's immigrants, and stressing the oft-ignored difference between legal and illegal immigration, Peggy Noonan makes a good case for Republicans to embrace immigrants with "sympathy and respect" ("Republicans and Immigrants Need Each Other," Declarations, April 17). To put a finer point on her electoral math: There are far more immigrants and U.S.-born children of immigrants than there are woke corporate executives who hire them as cheap labor. If Republican can count, they would be wise to focus more on courting the former as voters than the latter as donors.

title: Who Tells the Truth About Climate Change?
summary: Trying to reduce carbon-dioxide emissions is futile.. Regarding Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.'s "The Weekend Interview With Steven Koonin: How a Physicist Became a Climate Truth Teller" (April 17): Politicians want to believe that averages of different climate models have credibility beyond what science supports. Mr. Koonin is correct to conclude these models "are not to the standard you would trust your life to or even trillions of dollars to."

title: Cheating, Excuses and Redemption at West Point
summary: What's more stressful-passing a freshman-level calculus exam or maintaining one's leadership wits under enemy fire?. Hats off to the U.S. Military Academy for its decision to ax the "willful admission process," which has perverted West Point's honor code ("Cheating at West Point Spurs End to Leniency," Page One, April 17). While there is no doubt Covid resulted in unique challenges for students, officers in training at every military academy pledge at matriculation to uphold the highest standards of honesty and integrity. Fundamentally, it's a matter of always choosing to do what is right.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Supply Set to Outpace Demand
summary: State health officials are pivoting from managing a rush in demand to promoting the vaccine so the U.S. can reach herd immunity. The nation's supply of Covid-19 vaccines is set to outpace demand in the next two to four weeks, according to a national health nonprofit, as state health officials pivot from managing a flood of interest in the shot to persuading people to get it.

title: Climate Summit's Final Day Focuses on Technology, Innovation
summary: Officials weigh how to achieve emission-reduction goals laid out by world leaders. WASHINGTON-Officials from the U.S. and other nations spent the final day of a global climate summit focused on innovation, as they debate how to deploy technology and economic incentives to achieve the emission-reduction goals laid out by world leaders.

title: Carl Spielvogel, Co-Founder of a Hot Advertising Shop, Dies at 92
summary: Executive got his start as a newspaper columnist and volunteered for numerous public-service roles. Carl Spielvogel considered it the biggest disappointment of his career when he was passed over for the top job at the advertising giant Interpublic Group in May 1979. His setback proved very brief.

title: The Price of Glittering Glass
summary: In 18th-century Britain, the aristocratic taste for decorative glass was paid for in part by trade in slaves and opium. In the late 18th century, British aristocrats were "not supposed to reveal anything of their inner feelings, their inner lives," said Christopher Maxwell, curator of early modern glass at the Corning Museum of Glass in Corning, N.Y. Rather, they tried to present themselves as mirrors flawlessly reflecting the society they were part of, free from the "irregularities" of personal emotions. No wonder fashionable men embraced formal wear encrusted with dazzling glass-jewel embroidery, turning themselves into literal mirrors.

title: Mason-Dixon Poll: Americans Reject Court-Packing
summary: Independents overwhelmingly oppose plan to add Justices.. By a large margin, Americans oppose the idea of increasing the number of justices serving on the U.S. Supreme Court. That's according to a new nationwide survey of 1,100 registered voters conducted by Mason-Dixon Polling & Strategy. The survey also finds little support for ending the legislative filibuster in the U.S. Senate.

title: Jailed Russian Dissident Alexei Navalny Ends Hunger Strike
summary: Opposition leader says doctors advised him to end the hunger strike because it was threatening his life. MOSCOW-Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny said on Friday that he would end a weekslong hunger strike after he received medical treatment and his doctors warned that continuing to refuse food could kill him.

title: Oil-Field Services-Lots to Like Beneath the Surface
summary: Oil-services companies continue to see discipline from major oil producers and are demanding it of themselves too. How is the oil patch's recovery coming along? Slow and steady, judging by the three major oil field services firms that unveiled results in the past week. That should be music to investors' ears.

title: New York City Allows Walk-Ins at Vaccination Centers
summary: Anyone 16 or older can get a shot; geographic restrictions also are lifted. New York City will no longer require appointments at its Covid-19 vaccination centers and will permit anyone age 16 or older to walk in for a shot, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced Friday.

title: Jack and the Bean Counters: A Woke Children's Story
summary: University researchers use artificial intelligence to reduce characters to the color of their fictional skin.. One of my favorite childhood novels recounted the story of a boy separated from his family and caught behind Japanese lines in war-torn midcentury China. I felt I was with the boy, Tien Pao, when he woke terrified in a sampan sweeping downriver toward the smoldering ruins of his village. Alongside Tien Pao, I watched a doomed train back into a burning station and heard the screams of its passengers. Together we crouched in the broiling sun, scanning throngs of refugees for a familiar face. Later, we flew in a plane over an aerodrome and I felt his jolt of joy as if it were my own when, far below, he saw his mother.

title: Biden to Travel to U.K., Belgium in June
summary: In his first overseas trip as president he will attend the G-7 summit in England. WASHINGTON-President Biden will travel to the United Kingdom and Belgium in June, making his first overseas trip as president amid the coronavirus pandemic, the White House said Friday.

title: Google Maps to Add a Greenest Route to Its Driving Directions
summary: The app will use factors like road type, incline and traffic to recommend the least polluting route-so long as it takes no longer than the fastest one. Alphabet Inc.'s Google is tweaking its Maps app to highlight environmentally friendlier directions to users' destinations, the company said.

title: Nestlé Looks to Buy Maker of Nature's Bounty Vitamins
summary: Price being discussed for Bountiful is in the mid-single-digit billions. Nestlé SA is in talks to buy the maker of Nature's Bounty vitamins for a price in the mid-single-digit billions, according to people familiar with the matter, as the Swiss food giant pushes further into nutritional offerings.

title: French Police Worker Stabbed in Terrorist Attack Near Paris
summary: Killing by unidentified assailant, who was then killed by police, follows string of attacks late last year. PARIS-An administrative police worker was stabbed to death in an assault on a police station that investigators were treating as a terrorist attack.

title: 'The Free World' Review: Cold War Culture
summary: As the Americans and Soviets jockeyed for dominance, every page and painting was a potential battlefield.. There was once a time-Louis Menand recalls at the beginning of "The Free World: Art and Thought in the Cold War"-when "people cared. Ideas mattered. Painting mattered. Movies mattered. Poetry mattered." Even criticism mattered. It was a time when "people believed in liberty, and thought it really meant something." The United States was "actively engaged with the rest of the world." To be sure, the 20 years that followed World War II didn't frame a utopia: a fifth of the nation lived in poverty, "white men" dominated "virtually every sphere of life," the U.S. "intervened in the internal political affairs of other states, rigging elections, endorsing coups, enabling assassinations," and "invested in a massive and expensive military buildup that was out of all proportion to any threat." Nevertheless, Mr. Menand suggests, something extraordinary took place. American and European cultures were transformed by what transpired, and somehow the concept of "freedom" was bound up in it all as "the slogan of the times." This epic book-at once brilliant and exasperating, illuminating and confounding, absorbing and off-putting-is his attempt to examine what happened and to explain why, by the end of the Vietnam War, America was a very different country from the one that led the "free world" just after 1945.

title: What to Read This Week
summary: Louis Menand on Cold War culture, a lost novel from Richard Wright, the life of a real Renaissance Man and more..

summary: Chef Rashida Holmes of L.A.'s Bridgetown Roti shares her quick recipe for pepper-pot shrimp with fried plantains. On the table in under a half hour. No silverware required.. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Drop in Toilet-Paper Demand Prompts Kimberly-Clark Sales Decline
summary: Sales in consumer-tissue segment fell more quickly than company expected and supply-chain disruptions took a toll; more price increases are likely. Kimberly-Clark Corp. delivered its worst sales performance in at least a decade, hit by supply-chain disruptions, continued business shutdowns and fallout from last year's toilet paper hoarding amid the pandemic.

title: AmEx Needs People to Start Leaving Home Again
summary: Corporate travel spending on cards remains depressed, but trends such as younger spenders could help. The next time a banker or consultant calls and wants to fly out to see you, that might be a signal to buy credit-card company stocks.

title: Publishing's New Word Order: Audiobook First
summary: The author's company uses sound effects and original music. 'We think with our eyes and feel with our ears.'. Malcolm Gladwell's latest book opens with ominous sirens, planes droning overhead and a powerful explosion.

title: 'Early Morning Riser' Review: Small Town, Big Personalities
summary: In this latter-day Mayberry, everyone knows everyone else's business, for better or worse.. Jane Wilkes is a few weeks into her first year as a second-grade teacher in Boyne City, Mich.-we should all be lucky enough to have a second-grade teacher like Jane-when she meets Duncan Ryfield. If "Early Morning Riser," Katherine Heiny's wry, busy second novel, were a movie, the two would be described as meeting cute: Jane, who's pretty and blond and 26, gets locked out of her house early one Friday evening. Duncan, a woodworker by trade, a locksmith and (very dilatory) restorer of antique furniture by economic necessity, gets the S.O.S. call. He stays for dinner, and then, what with one thing and another, he stays for the weekend.

title: 'Other Worlds' Review: Sketches of a Spiritual Country
summary: With a deceptively light touch, the author known as Teffi conjured a Russia of everyday miracles.. The stories in "Other Worlds" conjure a vanished Russia. Candle flames flicker on the dark faces of family icons, a coachman bites into a black radish, and in the deep forest a wolf speaks with a human voice. Above all, this collection reveals the spiritual threads woven into the fabric of old Orthodox observance.

title: How Hubert Joly Changed Best Buy Without Everyone Hating Him
summary: In 2012, many predicted the end was near for the legendary Minneapolis electronics retailer. A new boss knew he would need to shake things up. The question was how.. When I joined Best Buy on September 4, 2012, the mood was grim. The previous CEO had been fired, embroiled in a scandal, and the share price was plummeting. Founder Dick Schulze had just launched his offensive to take the company private. Article after article predicted that the company would die, unable to weather market changes and low-cost online competition.

title: Pianist Kristian Bezuidenhout Plays Mozart and Beethoven As They Originally Sounded
summary: The period-instrument musician prefers an early 19th century-style fortepiano to today's concert grands. Classical music fans are used to hearing the keyboard music of Mozart and Beethoven performed on massive, seven-octave concert pianos, which were first introduced in the middle of the 19th century. Keyboard player Kristian Bezuidenhout, 41, has made it his mission to perform those works on the smaller, more delicate-sounding fortepianos that the composers actually played and that their Viennese audiences were accustomed to hearing.

title: Spicy Shrimp Recipe: A Peel-and-Eat Party in 25 Minutes
summary: Chef Rashida Holmes of L.A.'s Bridgetown Roti shares her quick recipe for pepper-pot shrimp with fried plantains. On the table in under a half hour. No silverware required.. JUST BEFORE the pandemic hit, Rashida Holmes launched Bridgetown Roti, an L.A. catering company specializing in Caribbean food made with impeccable produce. When she relaunched with a focus on takeout, her business blew up. "I've built this out of the pandemic and it's been a wild ride," she said.

title: Analog Dials, Rough Rides to the Rescue in Car Chip Squeeze
summary: Global car shortage is forcing buyers and manufacturers to adjust. That new-car smell is going to cost you this year as factories scramble to find chips, but a compromise can soften the blow.

summary: The Frick's move to Madison Avenue gives viewers the chance to see Giovanni Bellini's 'St. Francis in the Desert' in a new light-literally.

summary: Credit-card company says first-quarter profit rose to $2.24 billion. American Express Co. is seeing consumer spending start to normalize as Covid-19 vaccinations pick up in the U.S.

summary: Resume Subscription. A Connecticut-based hedge-fund manager has purchased a three-bedroom apartment at New York's 220 Central Park South, the country's most-expensive condo tower, for its full asking price of $33 million, according to the buyer's agent. The deal is the first closed resale in the building.

title: How to Keep Your Cool When Markets Are Sizzling
summary: When everyone around you seems to be getting rich quick, it's hard to control your fear of missing out. But buying assets just because they're hot is a good way to get burned.. Buy low, sell high.

title: How Electric, Self-Driving Cars and Ride-Hailing Will Transform the Car Industry
summary: The era launched by Henry Ford more than a century ago is coming to an end, and the big question is whether the U.S. can keep up with China in the new race. Welcome to the world of AutoTech.. When GM's very first car, the Chevrolet Classic 6, appeared on Detroit's streets in 1912, it ran on gasoline. More than a century later, in 2034, the very last GM car that runs on gasoline is scheduled to roll off the assembly line. Starting in 2035, GM intends to make only electric cars, from its least expensive model, the $4,000 Hongguang Mini in China, to the "handcrafted" Cadillac Celestiq at $200,000-plus. The other major car companies, from Ford and Toyota to Volkswagen and Volvo, are heading in the same direction.

title: U.S., Global Economy See Pickup as Services Revive, Factories Boom
summary: Surveys point to stronger growth as manufacturing accelerates and vaccinations rekindle customer demand. The U.S. and global economies are showing signs of stronger growth as factories continued to boom and service businesses began to see the benefits of vaccination programs.

title: Non-Covid-19 Patients Return to Hospitals, Clinics With Virus Cases Down From Peaks
summary: Surgery, emergency room and clinic visits resume as Americans get vaccinated, but many patients now are sicker. Patients returned to hospitals and surgery centers early this year as Covid-19 surges subsided and vaccinations continued, but many of those coming back are sicker, some of the nation's largest hospital companies reported.

title: What Happens Next for Derek Chauvin?
summary: Ex-Minneapolis police officer convicted of murder in George Floyd's death is expected to be sentenced in June. Following Derek Chauvin's murder and manslaughter conviction, his lawyer and prosecutors are now preparing for the next phase of his case-sentencing. Still left to be decided: how long the former Minneapolis police officer will spend behind bars for killing George Floyd while arresting him last year. He also faces a separate tax case.

title: Panasonic to Buy Blue Yonder for $7.1 Billion
summary: Blue Yonder helps retailers, manufacturers and logistics providers predict customer demand. Panasonic Corp. said it is buying U.S. supply-chain software provider Blue Yonder Holding Inc. from Blackstone Group Inc. and New Mountain Capital LLC for $7.1 billion in a bid to accelerate its software business.

title: 'The Man Who Lived Underground' Review: Richard Wright's Lost Novel
summary: The work the author considered his finest at last sees the light of day.. Richard Wright is best remembered for "Native Son" (1940), the novel that made him, at 32, the nation's first bestselling African-American writer, and the memoir "Black Boy" (1945). "Native Son" is the story of Bigger Thomas, a young black man who unintentionally kills the daughter of his white employers, disposes of her body, flees, and is hunted down, killing again before he is caught; on another level, it is the story of the nihilism that a virulently racist society can be counted on to produce.

title: Rémy Cointreau Sits Pretty in U.S. Drinks Cabinets
summary: America's liquor market is on a tear. Companies that own tequila and cognac brands are faring best.. U.S. liquor sales are booming, with top-shelf brands particularly well placed.

title: Fiction: Jhumpa Lahiri's 'Whereabouts' Review
summary: A chronicler of Indian-American lives explores a very different setting-and a different language.. In her 2015 memoir "In Other Words," about her adventures learning Italian, Jhumpa Lahiri includes a short story titled "The Exchange," the first piece of fiction she completed in her newly adopted language. The story imagines a translator who, overtaken by an urge to "produce another version of herself," jettisons her possessions and moves to a foreign city. One day she is invited inside the apartment of a dressmaker to try on clothing. While preparing to leave she becomes convinced that someone has replaced her sweater with a different garment; it feels unfamiliar, somehow wrong. The next day she realizes she was mistaken, but even so, the sweater seems to have undergone a "transfiguration." "Now, when she put it on," the story concludes, "she, too, was another."

title: Climate Summit: How Do You Cut 50% of Greenhouse-Gas Emissions by 2030?
summary: WSJ analyzed carbon-reduction measures in climate-change proposals. Now you can decide how to lower U.S. emissions to 50% of 2005 levels.. The Biden administration on Thursday announced a plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions to half their 2005 levels by 2030. The plan calls for action from federal and state governments, businesses and other groups to reach the target.

title: A Dad Fights to Bring Back School Sports. His Son Moves On.
summary: Resume Subscription. VISALIA, Calif.-Over the years, the three Walker boys gathered a trove of medals and trophies in football, basketball, track and swimming. Their father, Phil Walker, poured his heart into their pursuits and thousands of dollars into equipment, private leagues and training camps.

title: Vartan Gregorian Rescued New York Public Library From Squalor
summary: Immigrant from Iran, who has died at age 87, was president of Brown University and headed Carnegie foundation. When Vartan Gregorian became president of the New York Public Library in 1981, the Beaux-Arts monument was crumbling. Its 88 miles of bookshelves hadn't been dusted in 75 years, he reported. Drug dealers and pimps congregated on the peripheries, and the back of the building "had become New York's longest urinal," he wrote.

title: Scott Stuber Helped Netflix Disrupt Hollywood. Now He Wants to Conquer the Oscars.
summary: Scott Stuber on why the awards matter to the streaming giant, post-pandemic movie-watching and which A-list director he's trying to coax into a film deal. On Scott Stuber's watch, Netflix has turned into the biggest movie machine in Hollywood.

title: 'The Bookseller of Florence' Review: Manuscripts and Medicis
summary: As the Renaissance took hold, classical texts became the rage. Enter Vespasiano da Bisticci.. At crucial times in history, bookstores may serve as meeting places, where visitors gossip, share ideas, perhaps dispute pressing issues of the day. In "The Bookseller of Florence," Ross King relates the fascinating story of a bookstore run by Vespasiano da Bisticci, a Florentine born in 1422, whose shop on the Via dei Librai, or Street of Booksellers, sat at the center of Florence's golden age and its valiant recovery of ancient knowledge. Throughout, Mr. King holds up Vespasiano's life as a prism through which to survey the vast and astounding events of 15th-century Italy. After all, Vespasiano's most important clients included the "Renaissance type that combined cultural refinement and religious piety with obscene ostentation and murderous savagery," who nonetheless dreamed of life "free from the bustle of civilization," with "plenty of leisure for writing books and, even more, for collecting them."

title: The Thrilling, Totally Boring Adventures of the Newly Vaccinated
summary: A pandemic altered ordinary life. Shots are slowly returning us to our beautifully banal routines.. The text messages from vaccinated friends arrive daily, reading like notes from brave explorers on faraway adventures.

title: Five Best: Books on the Confederates' Lost Cause
summary: Selected by John Reeves, the author, most recently, of 'A Fire in the Wilderness: The First Battle between Ulysses S. Grant and Robert E. Lee.'. By Thomas L. Connelly (1977)

title: Mysteries: 'The Measure of Time' Review
summary: Defending an ex-lover's son takes Guido Guerrieri into a maze of memories.. Crime novelist Gianrico Carofiglio is a former anti-mafia prosecutor from southern Italy. His popular character Guido Guerrieri, based in the port city of Bari on the Adriatic Sea, is a principled and intelligent lawyer who is mad about books. Throughout "The Measure of Time" (Bitter Lemon, 285 pages, $15.95), translated by Howard Curtis, the avvocato keeps a volume at hand to fill any downtime in court-Kafka's aphorisms, for instance, or "Tristram Shandy," which Guido judges "a very great novel of digressions."

title: Covid-19 Is Still Raging in Much of the World as Global Cases Hit Record Highs
summary: New variants, pandemic fatigue and easing of lockdowns have virus surging in many countries. While hopes are rising that a rapid rollout of Covid-19 vaccines is helping to tame the pandemic in the U.S., in much of the world the virus is still surging.

title: 'Sensational' Review: Heyday of the Stunt Reporter
summary: The ambitious women who broke into 19th-century newsrooms often went undercover to get their scoops.. In late 1888, a series of articles in the Chicago Times triggered widespread outrage, both among its readers and within its newsroom. The first article was headlined "INFANTICIDE." In this and subsequent installments, an anonymous "Girl Reporter" described how she had tramped through the city's streets, visiting more than 200 physicians' offices claiming she was pregnant and needed help with this "problem"-and that money was no object.

title: Children's Books: 'The Rock from the Sky' Review
summary: Jon Klassen returns with a story of a dramatic new arrival.. If you come upon a group of children who have a shifty look, with their heads turned to one side and their eyes sliding around in a meaning way, chances are you're encountering kids who've just finished reading a picture book by Jon Klassen. Children love to imitate the expressions of his characters. Mr. Klassen's deadpan humor-in picture books such as "I Want My Hat Back" (2011) and "We Found a Hat" (2016)-has an existential bleakness that elementary-school-age kids for some reason find incredibly funny. For this audience, Mr. Klassen has outdone himself with "The Rock From the Sky" (Candlewick, 96 pages, $18.99), a book that contains five brief and connected stories involving three animal friends (a turtle, an armadillo and a snake, all wearing hats) and two characters from outer space: the titular rock from the sky and a long-legged, one-eyed alien.

title: Biden's Pledge to Slash Emissions Would Require Big U.S. Changes
summary: While American industries are already moving to address climate issues, the president's ambitious target would require them to accelerate transformation. Meeting President Biden's goal of sharply reducing U.S. greenhouse-gas emissions by 2030 would require dramatically reshaping key sectors of the economy.

title: 2022 Kia Carnival: A Great Minivan in an SUV Disguise
summary: Kia's seven- or eight-passenger multi-purpose 'family hauler' offers the livability and convenience of a three-row vehicle, with styling that sidesteps the minivan stigma. AFTER A BRIEF stint in the 2022 Kia Carnival SX Prestige ($47,770, as tested) I told my wife, Tina, that if minivans keep getting better we were going to need more kids. She wished me luck with that.

title: How Dara Allen Is Breaking the Fashion Mold
summary: "Dara is taking a seat at the decision-making table," says designer Prabal Gurung of the 28-year-old trans model and stylist. At age 5, Dara Allen began learning to write in cursive because she had seen the flowy script while watching Disney 's 1950 classic, Cinderella. She started by trying to copy the free-flowing letters she saw on her favorite VHS tape. Her mother spotted this and soon taught her the script. Her kindergarten teachers eventually asked the young child to stop until her peers also had learned the skill, which wouldn't happen for four more years.

title: 11 Ways to Get Beach-ready
summary: Model and stylist Dara Allen heads to Miami with a wardrobe of spring's most covetable clothes, including dazzling evening looks that bring a gust of glamour. There is no one-trend-suits-all formula this season. Instead, there are options for every hemline, hue and humor, especially when it comes to dressing up for sultry summer nights on the beach. Labels such as Burberry and Brooklyn-based designer Gogo Graham offer the opportunity to shine in crystallized netted tulle and scaled, metallic chains that evoke an optimistic, futuristic take on glamour. Perennially classic brands including Giorgio Armani and Michael Kors keep things retro-chic with sensual, flowing jersey options. A swingy minidress from Versace has a kicky spirit while Givenchy's deconstructed gown has a subversive edge. Whether one prefers the power of a Grecian goddess dress from Dior, the freedom of an open-backed Gabriela Hearst dress or the minimalist chic of a Peter Do piece, there's a perfect dress for everyone. And if that doesn't do the trick-just throw on Louis Vuitton's luxe take on a T-shirt and board shorts. -Kevin Huynh

title: Snap, Intel, Mattel, Silicon Laboratories: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Futures put stocks on course for their first week of declines since mid-March. Here's what we're watching ahead of Friday's opening bell.

title: Russia Raises Rates Amid Standoff With West, Signs of Economic Recovery
summary: Central bank increases its main interest rate by 50 basis points to 5%. Russia's central bank raised its key interest rate, a move that may help support the ruble amid tensions with the West, but also reflects a recovery that it expects will lift economic output to its pre-pandemic level by the middle of 2021.

title: Wilt Chamberlain Couldn't Make Free Throws. Joel Embiid Can.
summary: NBA teams can't stop him, so they foul him. But that strategy doesn't work on this Sixers star.. In the remarkable season when Wilt Chamberlain averaged 50 points and scored 100 points in a game, he also set another mind-boggling but more obscure NBA record: He attempted 12.6 free throws per 36 minutes. Teams couldn't stop him. So they fouled him.

title: Women Step Up Trading in Bitcoin, Other Cryptocurrencies
summary: Robinhood says quarter of trading in digital currencies is done by women, though that level lags behind their trading in stocks and ETFs. More women are investing in cryptocurrency, as Coinbase Global Inc.'s initial public offering and bitcoin's recent record-setting high help bring the asset class further into the mainstream.

title: The NFL Draft's Most Exciting Player Is a Tight End
summary: Kyle Pitts can become the highest tight end drafted in modern history because there has never been a prospect quite like him. Everyone knows how the 2021 NFL draft will begin. The Jacksonville Jaguars will take Trevor Lawrence, a quarterback. Then the New York Jets will take a quarterback. The San Francisco 49ers will also take a quarterback.

title: Wells Fargo Has Used Its Lockdown Time Well
summary: By focusing on consumer deposits, Wells Fargo is in position to be one of the biggest winners as rates rise. Wells Fargo 's time in lockdown may have at least one benefit: The lender has positioned itself to be a big beneficiary from rising interest rates.

title: A Deliciously Diverting Road Trip Through the Deep South
summary: This three-day itinerary from Nashville to New Orleans is stuffed with American history, sultry small towns and simple carbohydrates. YOU COULD drive from Nashville's Centennial Park to New Orleans's French Quarter in under eight hours but what a pity that would be. Opt instead to take the slower, far more scenic route. Follow the Natchez Trace Parkway and U.S. Route 61 to be transported through a landscape of hardwood forests and piney woods and across coffee-colored rivers, with a number of diverting detours along the way. Chief among them: The Mississippi towns of Tupelo, Oxford and Natchez-the latter best described as "Tiger King" meets "Gone With the Wind." From there drop into Louisiana for a po'boy sandwich in Baton Rouge before an early arrival in New Orleans to partake of its everlasting party.

title: China's Communist Faithful Flock to 'Red Sites' Ahead of Centennial
summary: Resume Subscription. JINGGANGSHAN, China-Chinese leader Xi Jinping has called for a rediscovery of the party's history, and here in the heartland of the faith, pilgrims are answering the call.

title: Battery Metals Are Hot, but These Miners Can't Get Investors
summary: Small mining companies in North America are struggling to attract funding, despite growing demand for lithium and cobalt for electric vehicles and batteries. TORONTO-Investors are pouring money into car companies, battery makers and clean-tech startups that are poised to benefit from the global economy's shift to electric power. But many small mining companies that supply the raw materials haven't been invited to the party.

title: Intel's Dreams Meet Reality
summary: Sharp drop in data-center revenue and profit underscores major challenges ahead for chipmaker. For Intel Corp. , it seemed like life was going to get a little better before it got a lot harder. As it turns out, both are happening at the same time.

title: JPMorgan Apologizes for Role in Soccer Super League
summary: The U.S. banking giant had pledged $4 billion to finance the teams joining the breakaway competition. JPMorgan Chase & Co. made a rare public apology, saying its role providing the financial backing for a new European soccer league was a misjudgment.

title: Hassan Stresses Independence as She Faces 2022 Election Threat
summary: Republican Gov. Chris Sununu could be a formidable challenger to New Hampshire senator.

title: Simone Biles Leaves Nike for Partnership With Athleta
summary: The gymnast will have her own performance wear line and activist platform at a female-focused apparel company. Superstar gymnast Simone Biles is leaving Nike Inc . , departing the sneaker juggernaut's roster for a new apparel partnership with Athleta that she says more closely reflects her values.

title: Stock Market Investors Must Keep an Eye on Corporate Cash
summary: During the pandemic, cash holdings surged-and the levels convey important information about likely future returns. Major corporations are sitting on a mountain of cash: a decadelong buildup was given another sharp lift by precautionary measures taken during the pandemic. Those balances are worth monitoring, because they have important implications for investment returns in the future.

title: Recycling Isn't as Clear-Cut as You Might Think
summary: Of the plastics generated in the U.S. each year, only about 9% is recycled. I just want to say one word to you. Just one word. Are you listening? Plastics.

title: SPAC Surge Pumps Up Junk-Bond Market
summary: Money from stock offerings is flowing into below-investment-grade companies at a pace not seen since the dot.com boom of the 1990s. The wave of cash raised by special-purpose acquisition companies is rolling into the junk debt market, aiding distressed companies and rewarding investors who own their bonds and loans.

title: Apple, Spotify and the New Battle Over Who Wins Podcasting
summary: Podcasts exploded in popularity during the lockdown and are on track to bring in more than $1 billion in U.S. ad revenue this year. The battle for podcast dominance is on.

summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Supreme Court Narrows Protections for Juvenile Offenders
summary: Judges need not find defendants permanently incorrigible before imposing life without parole. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court held that juvenile offenders need not be found permanently incorrigible before being sentenced to life imprisonment with no chance of parole, ending a series of decisions that had steadily expanded protections for children convicted of serious crimes.

title: China, India Complicate Biden's Climate Ambitions
summary: Resume Subscription. China and India, both with huge and growing appetites for energy, will play outsize roles in efforts to curb greenhouse gas emissions as the world seeks to come up with more ambitious targets on climate change.

title: Joe and Jen's Police Narrative
summary: Is 'systemic racism' really behind every tragic shooting?. Why wait for facts when the narrative is convenient? The day after a Minneapolis jury convicted former police officer Derek Chauvin of the murder of George Floyd, White House press secretary Jen Psaki weighed in on another police shooting in Ohio. This one happened less than 24 hours earlier, about 20 minutes before the Floyd jury delivered its verdict.

title: TravelCenters of America to Add Hydrogen Fueling Sites for Big Rigs
summary: Truck-stop operator working with electric-truck maker Nikola to start rollout in California; forms new unit to deliver alternative energy across its U.S. network. Truck-stop operator TravelCenters of America Inc. is stepping up its alternative-energy game as tougher regulations push the commercial transport sector to look beyond diesel fuel.
